isis.stitle: SPICER 14-INCH (356 MM) AND 15 1/2-INCH (394 MM) TWO-PLATE, PULL-TYPE CLUTCH - INSTALL

step1.para: Install a new pilot bearing in the flywheel. If the old bearing must be reused, clean and check it thoroughly.
Check fit of splined hubs of front and rear friction discs on the main drive gear splines of the transmission to be used. Hubs must slide freely for proper clutch release.

If the flywheel has been replaced, always check the surface and pilot diameters with a dial indicator to make sure total indicator runouts are within specifications. Refer to Transmission Clutch Housing and Engine Flywheel Housing.
Remove the flywheel. Remove the two set screws from each of the drive pins; then remove the drive pins using a punch and hammer ( Figure 24).

Install six new drive pins in the flywheel, equally spaced ( Figure 25). Make sure the shanks of the drive pins are a press fit in the flywheel rim, and that the heads are square with the friction face.

figure.caption: Figure 25. Install New Drive Pins in Flywheel

step1.para: Position intermediate plate over drive pins.

warning.para: Always use safety glasses to avoid eye injury. Use a brass hammer to install drive pins.

step1.para: Apply pressure to the intermediate plate in one direction and measure the clearance between each drive pin and slot on the same side of the pins ( Figure 26). The minimum clearance between the drive pins and the drive slots should be .006 inch (.152 mm). If the proper clearance is not obtained, re-check the drive pins for squareness.

figure.caption: Figure 26. Measure Clearance Between Drive Pin and Slot

caution.para: Never file the intermediate plate slots to obtain the correct clearance. Doing this will cause an unequal load on the pins. This is a frequent cause of a poor or no release complaint in newly installed clutches and can result in broken drive pins.

step1.para: When the alignment and clearance are correct, remove the intermediate plate ( Figure 27) and lock the drive pins in place with new set screws. You must use two 3/8 by 3/8 set screws to lock each drive pin in place.
Re-install flywheel to engine. Refer to engine manual for torque specifications.
Install the front-driven disc assembly ( Figure 28) in the flywheel with the side stamped "flywheel" facing the engine.
Install the intermediate plate in the flywheel, locating the drive slots on the drive pins ( Figure 29).

figure.caption: Figure 29. Install Intermediate Plate in Flywheel

step1.para: When installing Super Duty clutches, be sure to use three anti-rattle springs equally spaced between the drive pins. Install with the curved side of the hole toward the flywheel face ( Figure 30).

figure.caption: Figure 30. Use Anti-Rattle Springs When Installing Super Duty Clutches

note.para: Super Duty clutches have thicker intermediate plates and four ceramic buttons. Do not mix standard (three-button) and Super Duty (four-button) discs.

warning.para: Wear heavy gloves when installing anti-rattle springs. They have sharp edges.

step1.para: Insert the spline aligning tool ( Figure 31) through the hub of the rear driven disc with the side stamped "pressure plate" facing the transmission. Install the rear driven disc behind the intermediate plate. Be sure the side stamped "pressure plate" faces the transmission. Insert the aligning tool through the hub of the front driven disc and into the pilot bearing.
Position the cover assembly on the flywheel ( Figure 32) with the wear compensator assembly or lock strap aligned with the opening in the bell housing.

figure.caption: Figure 32. Position Cover Assembly on Flywheel

step1.para: Start the 3/8-inch minimum Grade 5 mounting bolts with lockwashers and tighten finger tight to hold the assembly in place. Bolts should be 1 1/4 working inches (33 mm) long.
Tighten the bolts progressively in the sequence shown ( Figure 33) to pull the clutch ring into its proper position in the flywheel pilot. Tighten to 34 to 38 ft-lbs. (46 to 52 N•m).

figure.caption: Figure 33. Tighten Bolts in Sequence Shown

caution.para: Failure to tighten the bolts as described can cause permanent damage and/or out of balance condition.

note.para: As the bolts are tightened, the wooden blocks should fall free. If they do not fall free, be sure to remove them.

step1.para: Remove the aligning tool. This may require a tap with a mallet.
Install the transmission. Refer to TRANSMISSION.
